update.description:
This builds on the double pendulum example using dart in pull request #12. With both physics engines installed, this branch provides a prototype of the physics abstraction layer. To simplify the build process and loading and finding plugin libraries, the `BulletDoublePendulum` plugin is added to the `ignition-physics-dart` library by using the same folder and adding symbols to the plugins.cc. It could alternatively be located in its own library file, or it could be called `ignition::physics::bullet::DoublePendulum` if we rearranged the code in subfolders, but this was expedient for this prototype.

I did have to relax some expectations in the test, possibly because `libbullet-dev` is compiled with single precision, while dart is using double precision. I also had to relax the expectations on repeatability after resetting the state; I'm not sure why. It could be that some state variables are missing or the solver should be reset in some way. At this point, I think that's ok; there will be different levels of accuracy for different physics engines, so we can think about how we want to encode different expectations.

Note that I initially made an ODE example in the [experimental/double_pendulum/ode branch](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-physics/branch/experimental/double_pendulum/ode), but I switched to bullet after I noticed that in upstream ODE, the hinge joint always reports angles between [-PI, PI], while this controller expects unwrapped angles. We have this feature in our fork of ODE, and this feature was added to bullet ([see upstream feature request](https://github.com/bulletphysics/bullet3/issues/42)). I will work on upstreaming some of the changes in our fork of ODE, but for now it was easier to make the example with bullet.

There are a couple non-urgent TODO items that I noted:

* I don't clean up any of the memory that I allocate with `new`
* bullet has some support for serialization, which might be useful for saving state
* it would be interesting to implement this example with btMultibody to try the new Featherstone API
update.title: Example: double pendulum with PID control using bullet

content.raw:
Looks ok. The plot of the errors:  
  
  
![plot1.png](https://bitbucket.org/repo/5q9rMzd/images/1049669840-plot1.png 'plot1.png')![plot2.png](https://bitbucket.org/repo/5q9rMzd/images/3849255041-plot2.png 'plot2.png')  
Tests coverage, code-check outputs, all that is the same than the previous PR #12.  
  
I would change and group the examples in a separated folder, like `examples/double-pendulum`. BulletMathConversions.hh should be in `include/ignition/physics/conversions` or similar in my opinion.
content.html:
Looks ok. The plot of the errors:


Tests coverage, code-check outputs, all that is the same than the previous PR #12.

I would change and group the examples in a separated folder, like examples/double-pendulum. BulletMathConversions.hh should be in include/ignition/physics/conversions or similar in my opinion.
